Tens of billions of dollars in U.S. imports from China are under a microscope in a developing trans-Pacific showdown between two of the world’s trading powers. The Trump administration’s decision to levy tariffs on Chinese goods is triggering threats of retaliation from Beijing and big concerns over U.S. exports , worries deep enough to pummel shares of American companies focused on manufacturing and international trade. The WSJ’s Bob Davis reports that President Donald Trump said the tariffs would hit goods with a combined total value of “about $60 billion,” although the administration said earlier they would cover $50 billion of imports. That amounts to about 10% of U.S. imports from China, and the administration chose 1,300 product categories that may be covered. China quickly fired a retaliatory shot back against what called a “vile” action, targeting for higher tariffs $3 billion in U.S. goods, including fruit, pork, recycled aluminum and steel pipes . Bigger items like Boeing Co. aircraft and soybeans weren’t on Beijing’s list, suggesting there’s still room for negotiations, or for the confrontation to escalate.
Uber Technologies Inc. is getting caught in the same quandary as shippers as it tries to grow in a boisterous U.S. freight market. The company looking for trucks in a high-demand period where capacity is commanding a premium, WSJ Logistics Report’s Erica E. Phillips writes, Uber Freight is facing the reality that its ride-sharing model won’t work for freight the way it does in matching passengers with automobiles . As the one-year-old business scales up, it’s contending with the driver shortage--just like other freight businesses. The app-based operator hopes new incentives, including discounts on fuel and equipment, will attract drivers to its platform. But the bigger lure may come if Uber can prove it can pay drivers faster than other load providers. That may push more established brokers to speed up their own payment terms, just as they’re trying to upgrade their technology.
An executive exodus at Whole Foods is raising concerns among suppliers. A string of top managers have left the grocery chain since Amazon.com Inc. acquired Whole Foods last year, including leaders in areas such as produce and local foods that are tied to specialty suppliers embedded in the grocer’s culture. The WSJ’s Heather Haddon and Laura Stevens report the companies say they’re making big strides in integrating operations and overhauling back-office functions , including inventory management. Whole Foods’ main distributor, United Natural Foods Inc., even reported a 19% year-over-year jump in business to the chain last quarter. Whole Foods invited top suppliers in to discuss their frustration with operational changes, including fee increases that may push them to other retailers. Such unrest across the supply chain is a typical concern after big mergers. But some suppliers worry the executive departures mean that changes in strategy will be deeper and longer-lasting than they had bargained for.
COMMODITIES The Port of Shanghai. Photo: Bloomberg News Chocolate is hot all of a sudden, at least for investors. The U.S. price for cocoa has surged 31% this year, making the chocolate ingredient one of the year’s stars in a rebounding commodities market. The gains aren’t necessarily coming because consumers are growing that much fonder of chocolate, the WSJ’s David Hodari reports, but because earlier expectations for an oversupply of cocoa have crumbled as production has weakened and traders have been rejecting more low-quality beans at ports. Cocoa prices have been especially volatile in the past couple of years, with futures swinging up and down at double-digit rates. The wild swings come in a market for final demand that is relatively stable, meaning buyers often stock up months in advance to protect against volatility. Still, demand for cocoa in Europe is growing rapidly, and that could push prices even higher, at least until production heats up again.

IN OTHER NEWS Business activity in the eurozone slowed for the second straight month in March. (WSJ)
France’s transportation systems slowed to a crawl amid strikes protesting economic overhauls . (WSJ)
Gross margins at Conagra Brands Inc. fell in its most recent quarter as higher shipping costs offset improved sales. (WSJ)
Ford Motor Co. is solidifying its partnership with Indian auto maker Mahindra & Mahindra Ltd. to lower development and production costs. (WSJ)
Human semen exports from the U.S. to Brazil have surged some 3,000% in seven years . (WSJ)
Best Buy Co. plans to stop selling phones in the U.S. made by China’s Huawei Technologies Co. (WSJ)
China gave the go-ahead to tech company Baidu to conduct open-road tests for its autonomous vehicles . (South China Morning Post)
Kohl’s Corp. has gotten one apparel supplier to pare its order-to-delivery time down to eight weeks. (Bloomberg)
McDonald’s Corp. says it will cut its greenhouse gas emissions 36% by 2030 from the restaurant chain’s 2015 level. (Fortune)
Toy mogul Isaac Larian wants to raise $800 million through a GoFundMe campaign to rescue Toys ‘R’ Us Inc. (Los Angeles Times)
Container volume at China’s biggest ports rose 10.7% year-over-year in February . (Journal of Commerce)
Lawyers and insurers pushed Maersk Line to move its fire-damaged container ship to DP World’s Jebel Ali container terminal rather than to Maersk’s own closer terminal. (Lloyd’s List)
Israeli container line Zim swung to a $50 million net profit for 2017 . (The Loadstar)
U.S. rail regulators say they are “increasingly concerned” about freight railroad service . (Logistics Management)
Online retailer Boxed says it has added high levels of automation at its Union, N.J., warehouse without laying off workers . (CNBC)
Sherwin-Williams opened a Waco, Texas, distribution center that includes robots named GallBot and PailBot. (Waco Tribune)
